trans-unit.source: Animates from the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Quaternion"></xref> value of the previous key frame to its own <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrame.Value"></xref> using splined interpolation.

This class is used as part of a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrameCollection> in conjunction with a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimationUsingKeyFrames> to animate a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Media3D.Quaternion> property value along a set of key frames.
A key frame defines a segment of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionAnimationUsingKeyFrames> to which it belongs.
Each key frame has a target <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrame.Value%2A> and a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrame.KeyTime%2A>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrame.KeyTime%2A> specifies the time at which the key frame's <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.QuaternionKeyFrame.Value%2A> should be reached.
A key frame animates from the target value of the previous key frame to its own target value.
It starts when the previous key frame ends and ends when its own key time is reached.

Spline key frames like <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame> create a variable transition between values that is determined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame.KeySpline%2A> property.
Splined interpolation can be used to achieve more realistic "real world" timing effects such as acceleration and deceleration.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame"></xref> class.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame"></xref> class with the specified ending value.
The ending value (also known as "target value") for the key frame.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame"></xref> class with the specified ending value and key time.
The ending value (also known as "target value") for the key frame.
The key time for the key frame.
The key time determines when the target value is reached, which is also when the key frame ends.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame"></xref> class with the specified ending value, key time, and <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.KeySpline"></xref>.
The ending value (also known as "target value") for the key frame.
The key time for the key frame.
The key time determines when the target value is reached, which is also when the key frame ends.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.KeySpline"></xref> for the key frame.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.KeySpline"></xref> represents a Bezier curve that defines animation progress of the key frame.
Creates a new instance of <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame"></xref>.
The new instance.
Interpolates, in a splined fashion, between the previous key frame value and the value of the current key frame, using the supplied progress increment.
The value to animate from.
A value from 0.0 through 1.0 that specifies the percentage of time that has elapsed for this key frame.
The output value of this key frame given the specified base value and progress.
Gets or sets the two control points that define animation progress for this key frame.
To understand how a <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame.KeySpline%2A> works, it is helpful to understand cubic Bezier curves.
A cubic Bezier curve is defined by a start point, an end point, and two control points.
The two coordinates in the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame.KeySpline%2A> define those two control points.
When describing key splines, the start point of the Bezier curve is always 0, and the end point is always 1, which is why you define only the two control points.
The resulting curve specifies how an animation is interpolated during a time segment; that is, the curve represents the rate of change in the animation's target attribute over the time segment.
To better see the relationship between animation progress and a Bezier curve, see [Key Spline Animation Sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=160011).
Dependency Property Information
Identifier field
Metadata properties set to `true`
None
The two control points that specify the cubic Bezier curve that defines the progress of the key frame.
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame.KeySpline"></xref> dependency property.
Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the animation uses spherical linear interpolation to calculate the shortest arc between positions.
Dependency Property Information
Identifier field
Metadata properties set to `true`
None
Boolean value that indicates whether the animation uses spherical linear interpolation to calculate the shortest arc between positions.
Identifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Animation.SplineQuaternionKeyFrame.UseShortestPath"></xref> dependency property.
